awd_titl_txt: Transforming Mathematics Teaching Through Making, Modeling and Mentoring
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, this Capacity Building project at Towson University (TU) aims to transform mathematics teaching using the practice of mathematical modeling and the emerging technology of makerspaces. Mathematical models are important because they can be used to explain systems and predict behavior.  Makerspaces, workspaces that encourage creative design using tools such as 3D printers, are becoming more common in K-12 schools.  Makerspaces can improve the mathematical learning of students because the students gain a better understanding of systems by experimenting, building, and tinkering.  However, professional development for teachers is critical for both makerspace technology and mathematical modeling to fulfill their promise of improving learning. To address this need, this project plans to establish the foundation to develop teacher leaders who can use making and modeling in their schools and mentor their colleagues in adopting them. Through this effort, this project plans to develop new graduate courses to train its students in making, modeling, and mentoring. There are also plans to create a regional network of partners to engage the community and ensure that the progress made through this project is sustained.  

This project aspires to build partnerships across the Baltimore region, bringing together TU faculty with stakeholders from Baltimore City Public Schools and Baltimore County Public Schools as well as mathematics teacher organizations and non-profit makerspaces. The primary goals of the Capacity Building project are to: (a) develop a coherent and connected sequence of courses to improve teacher knowledge and instructional practice in making, modeling and mentoring and (b) build and strengthen partnerships with local school districts and non-profit partners. The project will include a needs assessment which focuses on understanding what makerspace technology currently exists in these school districts, how it is being utilized, and the critical professional development needs of mathematics teachers. This needs assessment should inform course development as well as future plans for a Noyce Track 3 Master Teaching Fellowship program. Through a pilot implementation of the making and modeling graduate courses, this project plans to train teachers to effectively use makerspaces, iteratively improve the courses and add to the research base on technology education and mathematical modeling.  This project is important because it has the potential to serve as a national model for mathematics teacher education in makerspace technology and mathematical modeling. The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 mathematics and science teachers in high-need school districts and experienced and exemplary K-12 STEM teachers to become STEM master teachers. It also supports research on persistence, retention and effectiveness of K-12 teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Transforming Mathematics Teaching through Making, Modeling, and Mentoring was a collaboration between the Department of Mathematics and the College of Education at Towson University, in partnership with Baltimore County Public Schools and the Baltimore City Public School System.  The goals of the project were to use the practice of mathematical modeling and the emerging technology of makerspaces to inform transformative mathematics teaching. Makerspaces (spaces that encourage creative design, including through digital fabrication tools such as 3D printers) are increasingly present in K-12 schools, and can improve the mathematical learning of students who can experiment, build, and tinker.  However, professional development for teachers is critical for makerspace technology to fulfill its promise of improving learning.

Our project team addressed this need by developing a sustainable teacher leadership program, including a new curricular pathway within our existing Master of Science in Mathematics Education program.  In particular, we developed or modified four graduate courses in mathematics education to use the lenses of making, modeling, and mentoring to transform experienced and exemplary mathematics teachers into teacher leaders by increasing their technological expertise, mathematics knowledge, and leadership skills.  We also developed a new pilot course in integrating the practice of mathematical modeling with authentic social justice situations, building teachers? skills to help students use mathematics to understand and take action on critical issues. Over the funding period, we were able to pilot graduate courses in the use of makerspace technology, mathematical modeling, and student mathematical thinking to inform teaching and learning, reaching a total of over 110 enrolled students.  These students, all practicing mathematics teachers across the K-12 grade bands, have used their skills to directly impact the mathematics education of students in the Baltimore region. 

We also built partnerships across the region to support mathematics education broadly, as well as to inform a future submission of Noyce Track 3 (Master Teacher Fellows) grant proposal, planned for submission in 2022.  In particular, our collaborations with Baltimore County Public Schools (BCPS) led to the creation of three cohorts of teachers enrolled in a M.S. in Mathematics Education through the support of the Towson Learning Network (TLN).  These 50+ enrolled teachers started their degree programs (fully funded with the support of TLN and BCPS) between 2019 and 2021 and will complete their Master?s degrees between 2023 and 2025.  The graduate courses we developed and piloted will form part of their degree program, along with other courses in mathematics content and pedagogy.  We also formed a partnership with the Towson University Center for STEM Excellence, leading to new projects to infuse mathematics education with social justice goals and culturally-relevant pedagogy and further support our future Noyce Track 3 submission. 

A final goal of our project was to add to the knowledge base about teacher learning of mathematical modeling and makerspace technology. Some of our findings have indicated that teachers? participation in the makerspace-augmented mathematics instructional technology course led to increases in technological pedagogical content knowledge (TPACK) and an increased awareness and appreciation of the types of technologies that can be integrated into mathematics instruction. However, analyzing teachers? lesson plans involving makerspace technology revealed wide variation in their developed TPACK, even after a full graduate course.  We hypothesize that teachers? TPACK development for makerspaces, which we term MakerPACK, was heavily mediated by their beliefs about mathematics teaching and learning (Corum, Spitzer, Nichols, & Frank, 2020).

Another significant result involves the integration of sports and other kinesthetic activities with mathematical modeling.  Our findings suggest that the use of embodied activities within sports settings (such as studying rotation during figure skating jumps) can provide students with unique mathematical learning opportunities (e.g. Cheng & Nedwick, 2020).  Finally, we have found that mathematical modeling experiences embedded in a social justice context, such as creating mathematical models for the practice of gerrymandering, can help prospective and practicing teachers develop their mathematical content knowledge while also learning about relevant and pressing issues of fairness (Spitzer, Corum, Frank, & Kara, 2019).

Throughout these project activities and findings, we have advanced mathematics education in the Baltimore region and set the groundwork for a future Master Teacher Fellow program.
